title: The Cayley-Hamilton Theorem
content:
The Cayley-Hamilton theorem is one of the most important results in linear algebra. It states that every square matrix satisfies its own characteristic polynomial.

Given an n×n matrix A, its characteristic polynomial is:
$$p(\lambda) = \det(\lambda I - A)$$

The theorem says that if we substitute the matrix A for λ and interpret powers of λ as matrix powers, we get the zero matrix:
$$p(A) = 0$$

This is remarkable because p(λ) is a polynomial equation satisfied by the eigenvalues, yet the entire matrix A satisfies the same equation!

title: The Characteristic Polynomial is Monic
content:
A polynomial is **monic** if its leading coefficient is 1. The characteristic polynomial is always monic because when we expand det(λI - A), the λⁿ term comes from the product of the diagonal elements, which contributes exactly λⁿ.

For a 2×2 matrix [[a,b],[c,d]], the characteristic polynomial is:
$$\det \begin{pmatrix} \lambda - a & -b \\ -c & \lambda - d \end{pmatrix} = \lambda^2 - (a+d)\lambda + (ad-bc)$$

Note the leading coefficient of λ² is 1.

title: Degree Equals Dimension
content:
The characteristic polynomial of an n×n matrix has degree exactly n. This follows from the determinant formula: expanding det(λI - A), the highest power of λ that can appear is n (from the product of diagonal terms).

This has the important consequence that when we apply Cayley-Hamilton, the equation p(A) = 0 gives us a relation involving Aⁿ. This means Aⁿ can be written as a linear combination of lower powers!

title: The Main Theorem (Wiedijk #49)
content:
**The Cayley-Hamilton Theorem**: Every square matrix satisfies its own characteristic polynomial.

Formally, if A is an n×n matrix with characteristic polynomial p(λ) = det(λI - A), then:
$$p(A) = 0$$

The proof in Mathlib uses the adjugate matrix identity:
$$A \cdot \text{adj}(A) = \det(A) \cdot I$$

By working with matrices over the polynomial ring R[X] and carefully analyzing (XI - A) and its adjugate, the result follows from pure algebra.

title: Nilpotent Matrices
content:
A matrix is **nilpotent** if some power of it equals zero: Nᵏ = 0 for some k.

If N is nilpotent, all its eigenvalues are 0 (since if Nv = λv with v ≠ 0, then Nᵏv = λᵏv = 0 implies λ = 0). Thus the characteristic polynomial is just p(λ) = λⁿ.

By Cayley-Hamilton, p(N) = Nⁿ = 0. This proves that every nilpotent n×n matrix satisfies Nⁿ = 0.

title: The 2×2 Case
content:
For a 2×2 matrix A = [[a,b],[c,d]], the characteristic polynomial is:
$$p(\lambda) = \lambda^2 - \text{trace}(A)\lambda + \det(A)$$
$$= \lambda^2 - (a+d)\lambda + (ad-bc)$$

Cayley-Hamilton gives:
$$A^2 - (a+d)A + (ad-bc)I = 0$$

Rearranging (when det(A) ≠ 0):
$$I = \frac{1}{ad-bc}((a+d)A - A^2) = \frac{1}{ad-bc}(\text{trace}(A) \cdot I - A) \cdot A$$

This gives the inverse formula:
$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{ad-bc} \begin{pmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{pmatrix}$$

title: Applications and Significance
content:
**Computing Matrix Powers**: Since Aⁿ can be expressed in terms of I, A, ..., A^(n-1), any power of A (even A¹⁰⁰⁰) can be computed using only n-1 matrix multiplications.

**Matrix Exponential**: The exponential e^(At) is crucial in solving dx/dt = Ax. Cayley-Hamilton helps simplify the infinite series.

**Minimal Polynomial**: The minimal polynomial m(x) is the monic polynomial of smallest degree such that m(A) = 0. By Cayley-Hamilton, m divides the characteristic polynomial, so deg(m) ≤ n.

**Eigenvalue Connection**: If λ₁, ..., λₙ are the eigenvalues, then:
$$(A - λ₁I)(A - λ₂I)\cdots(A - λₙI) = 0$$

Remarkably, while each factor (A - λᵢI) may be nonzero, their product is always zero!

title: Historical Notes
content:
The theorem has an interesting history:

- **1853**: William Rowan Hamilton proves the result for quaternions (which can be viewed as 2×2 complex matrices)

- **1858**: Arthur Cayley states the theorem for general matrices in 'A Memoir on the Theory of Matrices', but only verifies it for 2×2 and 3×3 cases, writing 'I have not thought it necessary to undertake the labor of a formal proof'

- **1878**: Ferdinand Frobenius provides the first rigorous proof for arbitrary n×n matrices

Despite Cayley only verifying special cases, the theorem bears his name along with Hamilton's, recognizing their foundational contributions.
